text: you
before Hurricane Katrina washed it away
New Orleans had one of the lowest
performing school systems in the country
after the storm things looked even worse
all the teachers were fired the school
system was shut down and the students
were scattered all over the country now
three years later schools in New Orleans
are slowly recovering but the new system
looks very different than the one that
existed before the storm Chelsea Schmitz
is part of that transformation she's one
of hundreds of inexperienced but
idealistic young teachers who have come
to the city through programs like Teach
for America which recruits recent
college graduates to teach for two years
in low income communities across the
country i paid a few visits to schmitz's
ninth grade English class at remain high
in downtown New Orleans last spring she
had been teaching for seven months at
that point and she seemed comfortable in
front of her class but she told me that
when she first arrived in New Orleans
she felt a little alien she was
Midwestern and white in a mostly black
southern city and at 22 she was just a
few years older than some of her
students when I walked into the
classroom I'm in September fourth I
didn't really know what to expect at all
I didn't know what they would think that
I had anything in common with them and I
didn't know if they would be weary as to
what I was doing in New Orleans you know
I wasn't from New Orleans I wasn't here
during Katrina and therefore I probably
didn't understand a lot of what it meant
to be in New Orleanian all right many of
her students were well behind grade
level and she arrived and a lot of them
weren't really engaged with reading and
writing schmitz tried to figure out a
way to change that and she hit on the
idea of getting them to tell the stories
of their lives a lot of them chose to
write about Katrina which was you know
obviously a horrible time for them and a
lot of them have written about like the
violence that they've seen in the city I
found out my grandpa would a phone call
policeman had him and didn't get hurt at
all things lift it up for me after that
drama to the day we got hit by Katrina
category 5 we left the day before was
left this Vegas and my best friend front
door everything was cool to the day we
moved out I slept with my mama my
brother slept on a couch at the end of
May Schmitz took all her ninth grade
students on a field trip to the sound
cafe a small coffee house in the bywater
neighborhood she wanted them to have the
experience of sharing their stories with
a crap all right let's see if we've got

just said i want to sale it about what
